Literature Review: Phage therapy has emerged as a promising alternative to traditional antibiotics in the fight against bacterial infections. However, the evolution of bacterial resistance poses a significant challenge to the widespread adoption of phage therapy. In this review, we will discuss the two main strategies for mitigating bacterial resistance in phage therapy: minimizing the ability for bacterial populations to evolve phage resistance and driving (steering) evolution of phage-resistant bacteria toward clinically favorable outcomes. We will also examine the current state of phage therapy research and future directions for addressing the phage-resistance problem.
